body.p:
Augusta Ky
March 25th/63
Gov. Jas. F. Robinson
Dear Sir
At the last term of the Bracken Circuit Court a gentleman by the name of John Elliott was fined for giving a slave a drink of liquor -- It was done under the following circumstances --

Mr Elliott is, & was at the time a Hotel Keeper, and gave some young gentleman an oyster supper -- the owner son of the owner of the slave being one of the party -- upon that occassion in the presence of this young man, the son of the owner of
the slave, Mr Elliott give said negro a dram -- This is the whole case -- For this Mr Elliott was fined at the suggestion, or rather information of an Enemy, not the owner of the slave or any of his family -- As soon as he was indicted, Mr Elliott appeared before the Judge & confessed & was fined -- He did not for a moment dream under such circumstances, in the presence of the negros young master, he would even be subjected to any difficulty -- He informs
me that the Commonwealth Attorney, & Judge addressed you a letter about the 2nd of this month asking the remission of said fine -- Not having received an Answer, he fears you did not receive the communication -- & requests me to write again --
Mr Elliott is a gentleman of integrity & respectable standing in the community in which he lives, and I believe he intended no wrong, & under the circumstances the fine ought to be remitted --

I hope if consistent with your views of duty
you will remit the fine
T F Marshall ask remission Mr Elliots fine
